question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The data in the table below shows the percent of bus riders in a survey of Central H.S. students; 300 males and 300 females in each grade were surveyed. For which grade is the number of its male bus riders closest to $135\%$ of the number of its female bus riders? \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|}\hline
Grade & Males & Females \\ \hline
$9^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $41.1\%$ & $39.4\%$ \\ \hline
$10^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $34.4\%$ & $33.1\%$ \\ \hline
$11^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $20.6\%$ & $13.8\%$ \\ \hline
$12^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $11.6\%$ & $8.6\%$ \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
inference:
For $9^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade, male bus riders are $41.1\%$ of 300, which is $0.411 \times 300 = 123.3$. Female bus riders are $39.4\%$ of 300, which is $0.394 \times 300 = 118.2$. The number of male bus riders is $123.3$, and $135\%$ of the number of female bus riders is $1.35 \times 118.2 = 159.27$. The difference between the number of male bus riders and $135\%$ of female bus riders is $159.27 - 123.3 = 35.97$.

For $10^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade, male bus riders are $34.4\%$ of 300, which is $0.344 \times 300 = 103.2$. Female bus riders are $33.1\%$ of 300, which is $0.331 \times 300 = 99.3$. The number of male bus riders is $103.2$, and $135\%$ of the number of female bus riders is $1.35 \times 99.3 = 134.0$. The difference between the number of male bus riders and $135\%$ of female bus riders is $134.05 - 103.2 = 30.85$.

For $11^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade, male bus riders are $20.6\%$ of 300, which is $0.206 \times 300 = 61.8$. Female bus riders are $13.8\%$ of 300, which is $0.138 \times 300 = 41.4$. The number of male bus riders is $61.8$, and $135\%$ of the number of female bus riders is $1.35 \times 41.4 = 55.89$. The difference between the number of male bus riders and $135\%$ of female bus riders is $61.8 - 55.89 = 5.91$.

For $12^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade, male bus riders are $11.6\%$ of 300, which is $0.116 \times 300 = 34.8$. Female bus riders are $8.6\%$ of 300, which is $0.086 \times 300 = 25.8$. The number of male bus riders is $34.8$, and $135\%$ of the number of female bus riders is $1.35 \times 25.8 = 34.83$. The difference between the number of male bus riders and $135\%$ of female bus riders is $34.83 - 34.8 = 0.03$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{12^{\mathrm{th}}}$
ground_truth: The grade level in which the number of male bus riders is closest to $135\%$ of the number of female bus riders is the same grade level in which the percentage of male bus riders is closest to $135\%$ of the percentage of female bus riders. To find what percentage is $135\%$ of the percentage of female bus riders, we multiply each percentage by $1.35.$ In ninth grade, the percentage is $39.4\cdot1.35=53.19$ percent. In tenth grade, the percentage is $33.1\cdot1.35=44.685$ percent. In eleventh grade, the percentage is $13.8\cdot1.35=18.63$ percent. In twelfth grade, the percentage is $8.6\cdot1.35=11.61$ percent. From inspection, we see that $135\%$ of the percentage of female bus riders in twelfth grade is closest to the percentage of male bus riders in twelfth grade. So the answer is $\boxed{12}.$

9th grade:
Male: 0.411 * 300 = 123.3
Female: 0.394 * 300 = 118.2
135% of Female: 1.35 * 118.2 = 159.27
Difference: 159.27 - 123.3 = 35.97
